children.title: Math
children.tooltip: Watch videos and practice your skills for almost any math subject.

children.title: Early math
children.tooltip: Math begins with counting. It's the most important skill we learn in our early years and becomes the foundation for all other math concepts. Once we can count, we can add, subtract, and measure the world around us. Shortly thereafter, we can learn about place values, plots, graphs, time, money, and shapes. These early math skills are presented in this subject's tutorials in a straightforward, understandable, and (dare we say it) fun way!

Arithmetic
children.tooltip: So you're ready to have some arithmetic fun? You've come to the right spot! It's the first "official" math topic and chalked full of fun exercises and great videos which help you start your journey towards math mastery. We'll cover the big ones: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, of course. But we don't stop there. We'll get into negative numbers, absolute value, decimals, and fractions, too. Learning math should be fun, and we plan on having some with you. Ready to get started?

children.title: Addition and subtraction
children.tooltip: Adding and subtracting positive and negative whole numbers. Starts with 1+1=2 and covers carrying, borrowing, and word problems.

children.title: Intro to addition and subtraction
children.tooltip: Adding and subtracting is the basis of all mathematics.  This tutorial introduces you to one-digit addition and subtraction.  You might become pretty familiar with the number line too!
Introduction to addition. Multiple visual ways to represent addition.
children.title: Basic addition

children.tooltip: Introduction to subtraction
children.title: Basic subtraction
Adding and subtracting within 20
children.tooltip: In this tutorial, we'll start adding and subtracting numbers that have two (yes, two!) digits.  We won't be doing any carrying or borrowing (you'll learn what those are shortly) so you can see that adding or subtracting two digit numbers is really just an extension of what you already know.

Addition with carrying
children.tooltip: You're somewhat familar with adding, say, 17+12 or 21+32, but what happens for 13+19?  Essentially, what happens when I max out the "ones place".  In this tutorial, we'll introduce you to the powerful tool of carrying and why it works.
We're going to learn all about carrying when adding a 3 digit number. Join us!
children.title: Adding: three digit numbers

children.tooltip: Sometimes when we add, we carry our tens to the next column. Let's watch this so we can understand why it works.
children.title: Adding: why carrying works

children.tooltip: In the old days 'regrouping' was known as "carrying." It's the same idea now as then: moving the tens (or hundreds or thousands) over to the next column.
children.title: Adding: three digit numbers and regrouping

children.tooltip: More practice carrying with multiple digit numbers
children.title: Addition 4
Subtracting within 1000
children.tooltip: You can subtract 21 from 45, but are a bit perplexed trying to subtract 26 from 45 (how do you subtract the 6 in 26 from the 5 in 45).  This tutorial is your answer.  You'll see that we can essentially "regroup" the value in a number from one place to another to solve your problem.  This is also often called borrowing (although it is like "borrowing" sugar from your neighbor in that you never give it back).
Subtracting 2 digit numbers without regrouping
children.title: Subtracting 2 digit numbers without regrouping

children.tooltip: Introduction to regrouping (borrowing)
children.title: Introduction to regrouping (borrowing)

children.tooltip: Subtracting multi-digit numbers can be a little confusing when the top digits are smaller than the bottom ones. Let's look at regrouping together. It will help!
children.title: Subtracting: three digit numbers and basic regrouping

children.tooltip: When we don't have enough of something, we sometimes borrow it. Same in math! When there aren't enough tens (or hundreds, etc) to subtract with, we can borrow (also called regrouping).
children.title: Subtracting: three digit numbers and regrouping

children.tooltip: Getting a little fancier with our regrouping now. What if you have TWO numbers that require you to borrow or regroup? You guessed it! You have to take value from one place and give it to another.
children.title: Subtracting: regrouping twice

children.tooltip: In Kindergarten you learned the importance of sharing, right? In math, when we lack value in a number to subtract with you borrow or regroup from a neighbor. Sometimes you borrow from the tens...but what if you have zero tens? Ha....let's watch this and learn!

Basic multiplication
children.tooltip:
If 3 kids each have two robot possums, how many total robot possums do we have?

You liked addition, but now you're ready to go to the next level.  Depending on how you view it, multiplication is about repeated addition or scaling a number or seeing what number you get when you have another number multiple times.  If that last sentence made little sense, you might enjoy this tutorial.

One-digit division
children.tooltip:
Every time you split your avocado harvest with your 10 pet robot possums, you've been dividing.  You don't farm avocados?  You only have 8 robot possums?  No worries.  I'm sure you've divided as well.

Multiplication is awesome, but you're ready for the next step. Division is the art of trying to split things into equal groups.  Like subtraction undoes addition, division also undoes multiplication.  After this tutorial, you'll have a basic understanding of all of the core operations in arithmetic!
Introduction to division
children.title: Division 1

children.tooltip: Dividing Whole Numbers and Applications 1
children.title: Example: Expressing division in multiple ways
Starter multiplication and division word problems
children.tooltip: Math is super useful in the real world.  In this tutorial, we'll get some practice figuring out things that would have been tough without the powerful tools of multiplication and division!
If you think about it, multiplying is just another way of comparing numbers. How do we compare 4 and 20 using multiplication? Let's find out together.
children.title: Comparing with multiplication: basic exercises

children.tooltip: Multiplication helps us compare ages. Hint: learn those multiplication tables. They really help on problems like these.

children.tooltip: You know your multiplication tables and are ready to learn how to multiply *any* number (actually, any whole number).  Imagine the possibilities!  This tutorial will make you unstoppable.

Loooong division!
children.tooltip:
You know your multiplication tables and are getting the hang of basic division.  In this tutorial, we will journey into the world of loooong division (sometimes, referred to as "long division", but that's not as much fun to say).

After this tutorial, you'll be able to divide any whole number by any other.  The fun will not stop!
Dividing into larger numbers. Introduction to long division without remainders
children.title: Introduction to long division

children.tooltip: Do you like leftovers? (personally, we think they are delicious!). Those leftovers are like remainders in divisions problems. They're not bad. They just...are.
children.title: Dividing numbers: intro to remainders

children.tooltip: Let's work this division problem together. Our division is getting "longer" as the numbers get bigger, but that won't be a problem for you! Watch for the remainder.
children.title: Dividing numbers: example with remainders

children.tooltip: Here we go with more long division practice. Ever wonder why we call it "long" division? What's "long" about it, anyway?
children.title: Dividing numbers: long division with remainders

children.tooltip: Here's another practice example where you divide by two digits.
children.title: Dividing by two digits example 2

children.tooltip: Dividing a two digit number into a larger number
children.title: Level 4 division
Lattice multiplication
children.tooltip: Tired of "standard multiplication".  In this tutorial we'll explore a different way.  Not only is lattice multiplication interesting, it'll help us appreciate that there are many ways to do things.  We'll also try to grasp why it works in the first place.  Enjoy!
Introduction to lattice multiplication
children.title: Lattice multiplication

children.tooltip: Understanding why lattice multiplication works
children.title: Why lattice multiplication works
Partial quotient division
children.tooltip: Feeling constrained by traditional long division?  Want to impress your friends, family and even your enemies?  Well, partial quotient division may be for you (or it might not).  This very optional tutorial will show you that there are many ways to slice a walnut (just made up that colloquialism).
An alternate to traditional long division
children.title: Partial quotient method of division

children.tooltip: Another example of doing long division using the partial quotient method
children.title: Partial quotient method of division 2
Fancy multiplication and division word problems
children.tooltip:
In this tutorial, we'll start to challenge you with more sophisticated multiplication and division word problems.

If you understand mult-digit multiplication and long division, you have all the tools you need to tackle these.

May the force be with you!
It's time to start putting to practice the multiplication and division skills you've been building. Word problem fun!
children.title: Multiplication, division word problems: how many field goals?

children.tooltip: How many pizzas, pieces per pizza, and eaten pieces were there? Oh, the questions we must answer! It's enough to make you hungry.
children.title: Multiplication, division word problems: how many pieces of pizzas?

children.tooltip: Using multiplication and division to make estimates. Easy? Maybe, but what's more important is that you try.
children.title: Multiplication, division word problems: pedaling how fast?
Area models and multiplication
children.tooltip: Most of us learn to multiply eventually, but only a select-few actually understand what the multiplication represents.  This tutorial, with the help of area models, will allow you to be part of this elite group.
If you're like us, you're a visual learner. Seeing a multiplication problem visualized using an area model really helps. Check it out!
children.title: Multiplying: understanding by using area models

children.tooltip: Using graph paper we'll map out an area model to help us with a multiplication problem.
children.title: Multiplying: using an area model
Negative numbers and absolute value
children.tooltip: Extending our understanding of numbers below 0.  Thinking about "absolute" distance from 0.

children.title: Negative number basics
children.tooltip:
What is a "negative number"?  What happens when I add or subtract one of these?

If you come to this tutorial armed with the basics of adding and subtracting numbers, you'll learn about what happens in the world below zero!  You will learn what negative numbers are and how we can add and subtract them.
Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.
children.title: Negative numbers introduction

children.tooltip: Given a few negative numbers on a number line, let's see if we can determine what negative numbers are elsewhere on the number line.
children.title: Negative numbers and number line examples

children.tooltip: Is -40 bigger than -10? When ordering negative numbers from least to greatest, careful that you don't get hung up on the "amount" of the number. Think about what that negative sign really means!
children.title: Ordering negative numbers
Adding and subtracting negative numbers
children.tooltip:
You understand that negative numbers represent how far we are "below zero".  Now you are ready to add and subtract them!  In this tutorial, we will explain, give examples, and give practice adding and subtracting negative numbers.  

This is a super-important concept for the rest of your mathematical career so, no pressure, learn it as well as you can!
Using number lines and an understanding of absolute values, we walk you through the exercise of adding negative numbers.
children.title: Adding negative numbers

children.tooltip: Let's a take stab at adding numbers with both positive and negative signs. Using a number line makes this exercise easier and we recommend it.
children.title: Adding numbers with different signs

children.tooltip: Let's practice adding and subtracting both positive and negative numbers. Remember that two negatives make a positive, or another way of looking at, subtracting a negative is the same as adding.
children.title: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers

children.tooltip: Logic tells us (as does this video) that subtracting a negative number is the same thing as adding the absolute value of that number. Watch and be amazed.
children.title: Subtracting a negative = adding a positive

children.tooltip: Let's challenge ourselves with a word problem that requires us to plot points, positive and negative, and find the difference.
children.title: Negative number word problem

children.tooltip: Your checking account is overdrawn. Not good. Use your knowledge of decimals and adding negative and positive numbers to bring your account back into the black.
children.title: Rational number word problem with decimals

children.tooltip: Adding and subtracting negative numbers
children.title: Adding/subtracting negative numbers
Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
children.tooltip:
It is starting to dawn on you that negative numbers are incredibly awesome.  So awesome that you are feeling embarrassed to think how excited you are about them!

Well, the journey is just beginning.  In this tutorial we will think about multiplying and dividing numbers throughout the number line!
Here we explain some rules of thumb regarding the multiplication of positive and negative numbers.
children.title: Multiplying positive and negative numbers

children.tooltip: Why are the products of negative numbers defined in the way they are? We'll use the distributive property to help you with your understanding.
children.title: Why a negative times a negative is a positive

children.tooltip: We use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an intuitive understanding of multiplying negative numbers.
children.title: Why a negative times a negative makes intuitive sense

children.tooltip: In this video we take you through the basics of dividing with negative numbers. You'll need to draw from your multiplication skills, too.
children.title: Dividing positive and negative numbers

children.tooltip: Help us find the product of numbers with different signs.
children.title: Multiplying numbers with different signs

children.tooltip: Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
children.title: Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
Absolute value
children.tooltip:
You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero."  If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value.  If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value.  

As you'll see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extend to more contexts and dimensions, so it's super important that you understand this core concept now.
One easy way to think of absolute value is the distance it is from zero. To do that, a number line comes in handy. Watch and learn.
children.title: Absolute value and number lines

children.tooltip: Not only will we identify several absolute values in this example, but we will order them from smallest to largest. Content provided by The NROC Project - Â©Monterey Institute for Technology and Education
children.title: Absolute value smallest to biggest

children.tooltip: Let's mix a little algebra into our discussion of absolute value. What if we are looking for the |x|? If we know what x equals, we can do it. Follow along.
children.title: Absolute value of integers

children.tooltip: When we compare numbers we use the concepts of greater than (>), less than (<), and equal to (=). The same is true of absolute values.
children.title: Comparing absolute values

children.tooltip: Here are a few word problems that ask us to apply our new absolute value knowledge. As with all word problems, read them a couple of times before jumping to an answer.
children.title: Absolute value word problems

children.tooltip: Watch as we apply our understanding of absolute value and adding/subtracting negative numbers to solve some word problems.
children.title: Constructing and interpreting absolute value
Decimals
children.tooltip: Understanding decimals conceptually, using operations with decimals, rounding and estimating with decimals, and converting decimals.

children.title: Conceptualizing decimals and place notation
children.tooltip: You've been using decimals all of your life.  When you pay $0.75 at a vending machine, 0.75 is a decimal.  When you see the ratings of gymnastics judges at the Olympics ("9.5, 9.4, 7.5 (booooo)"), those are decimals.  This tutorial will help you understand this powerful tool all the better.  Before you know it, you'll be representing numbers that are in-between whole numbers all the time!
Decimal Place Value
children.title: Decimal place value

children.tooltip: By writing out a decimal in words, you're forced to really show your understanding of it. Give it a try!
children.title: Decimals: writing it out in words

children.tooltip: Here's another example involving writing out a decimal in words. Great practice.
children.title: Decimals: writing it out in words 2

children.tooltip: Let's expand a decimal out and really try to understand what it represents.
children.title: Decimals: expanding out place value

children.tooltip: Take your time and remember your order of operations as you translate this into a decimal number.
children.title: Decimals: writing it out as a number

children.tooltip: We're having a blast with decimals! Check this one: we're comparing place values. This will blow your mind.
children.title: Decimals: comparing place values

children.tooltip: Let's decide the number of each place value to make the given decimal. We can do it together!
children.title: Decimals: choosing a number to represent place value
Regrouping decimals
children.tooltip: Let's explore how we can regroup and redistribute value among the various place values in a decimal number.
We're doing more regrouping but this time using decimals. Just remember those place values!
children.title: Regrouping with decimals

children.tooltip: Similar to a problem we did earlier but with whole numbers, this time we're having to regroup with decimals and find the right answer. Take your time.
children.title: Regrouping with decimals example 1

children.tooltip: Great decimal regrouping exercise. Do this one with us and see how well you've mastered the regrouping decimal topic!
children.title: Regrouping decimals example 2
Decimals on a number line
children.tooltip: Let's think about where decimals are on a number line.  It will help us understand what decimals represent in general!
Let's compare decimals on a number line, shall we?
children.title: Decimals on a number line

children.tooltip: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.
children.title: Decimals and fractions on a number line

children.tooltip: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.
children.title: Placing positive and negative decimals on a number line
Comparing decimals
children.tooltip: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!
When comparing decimals it's easy to get confused by the number of digits to the right of decimal. Is it a tenth, hundredth, or thousandth? This video will help you a lot!
children.title: Comparing decimals example 1

children.tooltip: We're using the less than () symbols to compare decimals now. Cool!
children.title: Comparing decimals example 2

children.tooltip: Confused trying to determine which decimal is larger? Let's compare two decimals in this example. Remember that you're looking for the difference is the largest place value to find the larger decimal.
children.title: Comparing decimals: difference in largest place value

children.tooltip: It's not uncommon to be asked to compare two decimals and judge which one is larger. How do you do that? This video will gave you the confidence to answer that question.
children.title: Comparing decimals: place value difference

children.tooltip: This is a fun example where we reorder decimals from smallest to largest. You're looking for the place value that is the most signifiant, and then working backwards.
children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from least to greatest

children.tooltip: Let's move the decimals around and reorder them from least to greatest. Hint: look at one place value and then compare it to the decimals before moving on to the next place value.
children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from smallest to biggest
Adding and subtracting decimals
children.tooltip: You get the general idea of decimal is and what the digits in different places represent (place value).  Now you're ready to do something with the decimals.  Adding and subtracting is a good place to start.  This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally).  Have fun!
Line those decimals up first. Careful!
children.title: Adding decimals: example 1

children.tooltip: Let's practice another adding decimal problem. We'll do it together.
children.title: Adding decimals: example 2

children.tooltip: We're adding 3 decimal numbers together in this example. Give it a try!
children.title: Adding decimals: example 3

children.tooltip: Subtracting decimals...up to the hundredths placement. Line up those decimals before you start.
children.title: Subtracting decimals: example 1

children.tooltip: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.
children.title: Subtracting decimals example 1

children.tooltip: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work. We sound like a broken record, but be sure and ALIGN DECIMALS.
children.title: Adding decimals word problem

children.tooltip: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.
children.title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problem

children.tooltip: Subtracting decimal numbers
children.title: Subtracting decimals (old)
Multiplying decimals
children.tooltip: The real world is seldom about whole numbers.  If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal.  If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).
Multiplying decimals can be confusing because there's always the question as to where the decimals goes in the answer. We're about to show you so you'll never have to question it again!
children.title: Introduction to multiplying decimals

children.tooltip: We're multiplying decimals again, but this time answering a common question: what's the cost of filling up the car tank?
children.title: Multiplying decimals word problem

children.tooltip: We want you to develop an intuition about how to work with decimals. Understanding how you can rewrite decimals by considering the place value will help you multiply!
children.title: Multiplying decimals: place value and reordering

children.tooltip: Multiplying decimals? Try multiplying without the decimals first, them add them back in. We'll show you.
children.title: Multiplying decimals example

children.tooltip: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.
children.title: Multiplying challenging decimals
Dividing decimals
children.tooltip: You can add, subtract and multiply decimals.  You know you'd feel a bit empty if you couldn't divide them as well. But something more powerful is going to happen.  If you are like us, you never quite liked those pesky remainders when dividing whole numbers.  Well, those pesky remainders better watch out because they are going to be divided too!!!! Ah ha ha ha ha!!!!!
Sometimes, in order divide numbers completely you have to add a decimal and bring down places. Let's do it together, shall we?
children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer

children.tooltip: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is smaller than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.
children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2

children.tooltip: You're doing great. Now we want to mix it up a little: divide a decimal by a whole number. Follow along.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a whole number

children.tooltip: When dividing a whole number by a decimal, you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.
children.title: Dividing a whole number by a decimal

children.tooltip: Let's do one more decimal division problem together but change it up. This is one with a decimal divisor and will require you to shift the decimal first.
children.title: Dividing by a multi-digit decimal

children.tooltip: The old saying is "practice makes perfect." Let's keep practicing dividing decimals and making our divisor a whole number.
children.title: Dividing decimals with hundredths example 3
Converting between fractions and decimals
children.tooltip: Both fractions and decimals are desperate to capture that little part of our heart that desires to express non-whole numbers.  But must we commit?  Can't we have business in the front and party in the back (younger people should look up the word "mullet" to see a hair-style worth considering for your next trip to the barber)?  Can't it look like a pump, but feel like a sneaker?  Well, if 18-wheelers can turn into self-righteous robots, then why can't decimals and fractions turn into each other?
Sometimes when you convert a fraction to a decimal you have to do some long division and rounding.
children.title: Fraction to decimal with rounding

children.tooltip: This is a great example of converting a fraction to a decimal. Use a scratch pad so you can follow along.
children.title: Fraction to decimal example

children.tooltip: How to express a fraction as a decimal
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals

children.tooltip: Converting fractions to decimals sometimes requires us to brush up on our long division skills. We'll walk you through it.
children.title: Fraction to decimal

children.tooltip: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.
children.title: Decimal to simplified fraction

children.tooltip: We're practicing how to convert a lonely decimal into a happy fraction.
children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 1

children.tooltip: Being a decimal is hard. Everyone picks on you. Not like those lucky fractions. Let's convert the decimal together.
children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 2

children.tooltip: Converting this decimal results in a fraction that needs to be simplified. Can you help us?

Intro to percentages
children.tooltip:
At least 50% of the math that you end up doing in your real life will involve percentages.  We're not really sure about that figure, but it sounds authoritative.  Anyway, unless you've watched this tutorial, you're really in no position to argue otherwise.

As you'll see "percent" literally means "per cent" or "per hundred".  It's a pseudo-decimally thing that our society likes to use even though decimals or fractions alone would have done the trick.  Either way, we're 100% sure you'll find this useful.
Let's start by thinking about what percent really means. Once you understand this, other pieces will begin to fall into place.
children.title: The meaning of percent

children.tooltip: How does our meaning of percent (per "hundred") translate when we need to understand a percent OVER a hundred?
children.title: The meaning of percent over 100

children.tooltip: You'll find that be able to move easily between percentages, decimals, and fractions is HUGELY helpful. So let's practice!
children.title: Converting percent to decimal and fraction

children.tooltip: Need to convert a decimal to a percent? Ok, we'll just use our fraction friends to get us there. Watch and be amazed.
children.title: Converting decimals to percents

children.tooltip: Understanding how to convert a decimal to a percent comes in really handy sometimes. Let's practice using this problem.
children.title: Converting decimals to percents example 2

children.tooltip: Remember that "per cent" means "per hundred." Knowing that, converting a percent to a decimal is done by dividing by a 100. We'll demonstrate.
children.title: Converting percents to decimals

children.tooltip: Practice another conversion problem, this time from percent to decimal. Arriving at the answer is as simple as dividing by 100!
children.title: Converting percents to decimals example 2

children.tooltip: Once again, fractions are our friends as we use them to find a percentage. You'll also see a couple of different ways to arrive at the answer.
children.title: Finding a percentage

children.tooltip: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!
children.title: Percent word problem example 2

children.tooltip: We hope you're beginning to see that there's more than one way to skin a cat. In other words, there are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages, decimals, and fractions. Watch as find the percentage of a whole number.
children.title: Percentage of a whole number

children.tooltip: Identifying Percent Amount and Base
children.title: Identifying percent amount and base

children.tooltip: Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2
children.title: Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2

children.tooltip: Ordering numbers expressed as decimals, fractions, and percentages
children.title: Ordering numeric expressions

children.tooltip: As our earlier example, the goal is to simply the fraction and then convert it--this time in terms of hundredths.
children.title: Rewriting fraction as a decimal to the hundredths place

children.tooltip: Let's watch as Sal gives us a basic example of how to rewrite a fraction as a decimal. This will make a lot of sense!
children.title: Basic example of rewriting a fraction as a decimal
Percent word problems
children.tooltip: Whether you're calculating a tip at your favorite restaurant or figuring out how many decades you'll be paying your student debt because of the interest, percents will show up again and again and again in your life.  This tutorial will expose you to some of these problems before they show up in your actual life so you can handle them with ease (kind of like a vaccine for the brain).  Enjoy.
In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.
children.title: Growing by a percentage

children.tooltip: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.
children.title: Solving percent problems

children.tooltip: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.
children.title: Percent word problem example 4

children.tooltip: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage.We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!
children.title: Percent word problem example 5
Estimating and rounding with decimals
children.tooltip:
Laziness is usually considered a bad thing.  But sometimes, it is useful to be lazy in a smart way.  Why do a big, hairy calculation if you just need a rough estimate? Why keep track of 2.345609 when you only need 2.35? 

This tutorial will get you comfortable with sometimes being a little rough with numbers.  By being able to round and estimate them, it'll only add one more tool to your toolkit.
Rounding. Oh my....there will be so many times when rounding numbers (including decimals) will be a required skill. Let's get this down, shall we?
children.title: Rounding decimals: to the nearest tenth
Significant figures
children.tooltip:
There is a strong temptation in life to appear precise, even when you are aren't accurate.   If you  precisely measure one dimension of a carpet to be 3.256 meters and eyeball the other dimensional to be "roughly 2 meters", can you really claim that the area is  6.512 square meters (3.256 x 2)?  Isn't that a little misleading?  

This tutorial gets us thinking about this conundrum and gives us the best practices that scientists and engineers use to not mislead each other.
Introduction to significant figures
children.title: Significant figures

children.tooltip: Understanding the "rules of thumb" for significant figures
children.title: More on significant figures

children.tooltip: Addition and Subtraction with Significant Figures
children.title: Addition and subtraction with significant figures

children.tooltip: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures
children.title: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures
Moving the decimal to multiply and divide by 10
children.tooltip: In our decimal number system, as we move places to the left, the place values increase by a factor of 10 (likewise, they decrease by a factor of 10 as we move rightward).  This idea gets direct application when we multiply or divide a decimal number by 10 because it has the effect of shifting every place value one to the right or left (sometime seen as moving the decimal point).
You will notice in this word problem that moving the decimal to the right the same number of times as the number of zeros you multiplying by gets you the answer you desire. Check this out!
children.title: Multiplying a decimal by a power of 10

children.tooltip: When we were multiplying, we moved the decimal to the right for each power of ten. Guess what? When dividing, we move the decimal to the left for each power of ten.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10

children.tooltip: Holy cow! A shortcut? Yep. For each ten you multiply or divide by, just shift that decimal to the right or left. Watch this and be amazed.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10: shortcut
Adding and subtracting decimals, percentages, and fractions
children.tooltip: If you think you know how to convert between decimals, fractions and percentages and are familiar with negative numbers, this tutorial is a good place to test all of those skills at the same time.

In this example, we solve an addition problem with numbers in different formats: a percentage, decimal, and mixed number. First, we'll get them all in the same format...which makes it a while easier to solve!
children.title: Adding, subtracting numbers in different formats

children.tooltip: What happens when we are asked to add or subtract fractions, decimals, and percentages? You'll see in this example that we first get them in the same format, and then add fractions.
children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions, decimals, percentages

children.tooltip: Our focus here is on learning to multiply fractions. First we have to get the common denominator, then add positive and negative numbers.
children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions
Fractions
children.tooltip: Understanding fractions conceptually, using operations with fractions, and converting fractions.

children.title: Understanding fractions
children.tooltip:
If you don't understand fractions, you won't be even 1/3 educated.  Glasses will seem half empty rather than half full.  You'll be lucky to not be duped into some type of shady real-estate scheme or putting far too many eggs in your cake batter.

Good thing this tutorial is here.  You'll see that fractions allow us to view the world in entirely new ways.  You'll see that everything doesn't have to be a whole.  You'll be able to slice and dice and then put it all back together (and if you order now, we'll throw in a spatula warmer for no extra charge).

Visualizing equivalent fractions
children.tooltip: Do you want 2/3 or 4/6 of this pizza?  Doesn't matter because they are both the same fraction.  This tutorial will help us explore this idea by really visualizing what equivalent fractions represent.
To understand equivalent fractions it helps to "see" the fractions using something like a grid with shaded and unshaded sections representing the fraction. This will help a ton!
children.title: Visualizing equivalent fractions

children.tooltip: Your teachers will tell you that being able to apply (or put to use) concepts helps you to learn them better. Here's a word problem in which you have to apply your knowledge of equivalent fractions.
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example

children.tooltip: How do you find an equivalent fraction? If you know the denominator of both fractions, and the numerator of one of them...you can figure out the rest We'll show you in this word problem.
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 2

children.tooltip: We're comparing fractions using the info given in this word problem. Can you find the equivalent one?
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 3

children.title: Fractions cut and copy 1 exercise
Equivalent fractions and simplified form
children.tooltip:
There are literally infinite ways to represent any fraction (or number for that matter).  Don't believe us?  Let's take 1/3.  2/6, 3/9, 4/12 ... 10001/30003 are all equivalent fractions (and we could keep going)!  

If you know the basics of what a fraction is, this is a great tutorial for recognizing when fractions are equivalent and then simplifying them as much as possible!

Decomposing fractions
children.tooltip: In this tutorial, we'll see that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.  You might see the world in a completely different way after this.
It helps to visually understand what decomposing a fraction looks like. We're pretty sure you're going to like this.
children.title: Decomposing a fraction visually

children.tooltip: Decomposing mixed numbers is a pretty straightforward process. It's as simple as adding fractions with like denominators. Watch us do it!

Adding and subtracting fractions
children.tooltip:
You've already got 2 cups of sugar in the cupboard.  Your grandmother's recipe for disgustingly-sweet-fudge-cake calls for 3 and 1/3 cups of sugar.  How much sugar do you need to borrow from you robot neighbor?

Adding and subtracting fractions is key.  It might be a good idea to look at the equivalent fractions tutorial before tackling this one.
With like denominators, you're basically just adding numerators. That's not too bad, right? Can the resulting fraction be simplified?
children.title: Adding fractions with like denominators

children.tooltip: Just like when we added...subtracting fractions is pretty straightforward when the two fractions have like denominators.
children.title: Subtracting  fractions with like denominators

children.tooltip: You mean a spider has MORE than 2 eyes? Yikes!
children.title: Word problem: What fraction of spider eyes are looking at me?

children.tooltip: Better get practicing, Pedro! You have exactly (a fraction) more of an hour to practice the piano.
children.title: Word problem: What fraction of an hour should the piano still be practiced?

children.tooltip: Add the fractions to find out how long this lizard is.
children.title: Word problem: How long is this lizard?
Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
children.tooltip: We've already had some good practice adding fractions with like denominators.  We'll now add fractions with unlike denominators. This is a very big deal.  After this tutorial, you'll be able to add, pretty much, any two (or three or four or... ) fractions!
A great way to learn how to add fractions with unlike demoninators is to do so with denominators in units of 10 and 100. Like this...

children.tooltip: How to add and subtract fractions.
children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions

children.tooltip: To solve this problem, we need to find the least common multiple to get at the common denominator. Can you help? We bet you can!
children.title: Adding fractions: different denominators

children.tooltip: To add these fractions we need to find a common denominator. The answer can be expressed as a mixed number. Let's try together.
children.title: Adding fractions: common denominator

Adding and subtracting with unlike denominator word problems
children.tooltip: You know what a fraction is and are now eager to apply this knowledge to real-world situations (especially ones where the denominators aren't equal)?  Well, you're about to see that adding and subtracting fractions is far more powerful (and fun) then you've ever dreamed possible!
We can do math problem all day long, but to really understand math--you have to apply it. Let's apply adding fractions to this word problem.

Multiplying fractions
children.tooltip:
What is 2/3 of 2/3? If 4/7 of the class are boys, how many boys are there?

Multiplying fractions is not only super-useful, but super-fun as well.
Don't let multiplying whole numbers and factions get you down. We got this. This explanation will help you become a pro.
children.title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers

children.tooltip: This video will help you think about what it means to multiply two fractions. By drawing the problem and "seeing" the answer, you'll better understand how we arrived at it.

children.tooltip: Let's practice multiplying two fractions together. We'll learn to simplify the answer, too.
children.title: Multiplying two fractions: example

children.tooltip: Let's take a stab on practicing one of the most commonly used math skills: multiplying and dividing fractions. We'll use a few examples with negative numbers.
children.title: Multiplying negative and positive fractions

children.tooltip: When multiplying fractions, it's sometimes helpful to view the operation as a kind of scaling--that multiplying the fraction times another creates a fractional proportion, or scale. Watch. You'll understand.
children.title: Multiplication as scaling
Multiplying fractions word problems
children.tooltip:
Multiplying fractions is useful. Period. That's all we really have to say.  Believe us don't believe us.  You'll learn eventually.  

This tutorial will have you multiplying in real-world scenarios (which is almost as fun as completely artificial, fake scenarios).
We want to do a movie marathon! Let's figure out how long our marathon will last if each movie length is represented as a mixed number.
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: movie marathon

children.tooltip: Who doesn't love milk? Our family sure does. Let's figure out how much milk is consumed each month if each person consumes a fractional amount of milk.
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: milk love

children.tooltip: Oops! Someone tried to solve this problem and made a mistake. See if you can spot the error.
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: pigging out on pumpkin pie

children.tooltip: We hope you learn to cook. Everyone should! At some point you'll need to make 1/2 a recipe which means using 1/2 of every ingredient in the recipe. Here's an example.
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: banana oat muffin recipe

children.tooltip: Someone is about to run out of laundry detergent which means sticky clothes! Help her estimate how much she has left.
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: laundry emergency

children.tooltip: You know how long it takes to bike to your friend's house, and you know how fast your can ride. So how far away does your friend live? The answer is one fraction multiplication problem away!
children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: bike to a friend
Mixed numbers and improper fractions
children.tooltip: We can often have fractions whose numerators are not less than the denominators (like 23/4  or 3/2 or even 6/6).  These top-heavy friends are called improper fractions.  Since they represent a whole or more (in absolute terms), they can also be expressed as a combination of a whole number and a "proper fraction" (one where the numerator is less than the denominator) which is called a "mixed number."  They are both awesome ways of representing a number and getting acquainted with both (as this tutorial does) is super useful in life!

Dividing fractions
children.tooltip: This is one exciting tutorial.  In it, we will understand that fractions can represent division (and the other way around).  Then we will create fractions by dividing whole numbers and then start dividing the fractions themselves.  We'll see that dividing by something is the exact same thing as multiplying by that thing's reciprocal!
Remember that a whole number is actually a fraction, too? In this video we'll look at dividing whole numbers as fractions and how that leads to fractional answers!

Pre-algebra
children.tooltip: No way, this isn't your run of the mill arithmetic. This is Pre-algebra. You're about to play with the professionals. Think of pre-algebra as a runway. You're the airplane and algebra is your sunny vacation destination. Without the runway you're not going anywhere. Seriously, the foundation for all higher mathematics is laid with many of the concepts that we will introduce to you here: negative numbers, absolute value, factors, multiples, decimals, and fractions to name a few. So buckle up and move your seat into the upright position. We're about to take off!

children.title: Negative numbers and absolute value
children.tooltip: None

children.title: Negative number basics
children.tooltip:
What is a "negative number"?  What happens when I add or subtract one of these?

If you come to this tutorial armed with the basics of adding and subtracting numbers, you'll learn about what happens in the world below zero!  You will learn what negative numbers are and how we can add and subtract them.
Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.
children.title: Negative numbers introduction

children.tooltip: Given a few negative numbers on a number line, let's see if we can determine what negative numbers are elsewhere on the number line.
children.title: Negative numbers and number line examples

children.tooltip: Is -40 bigger than -10? When ordering negative numbers from least to greatest, careful that you don't get hung up on the "amount" of the number. Think about what that negative sign really means!
children.title: Ordering negative numbers
Adding and subtracting negative numbers
children.tooltip:
You understand that negative numbers represent how far we are "below zero".  Now you are ready to add and subtract them!  In this tutorial, we will explain, give examples, and give practice adding and subtracting negative numbers.  

This is a super-important concept for the rest of your mathematical career so, no pressure, learn it as well as you can!
Let's practice adding and subtracting both positive and negative numbers. Remember that two negatives make a positive, or another way of looking at, subtracting a negative is the same as adding.
children.title: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers

children.tooltip: Using number lines and an understanding of absolute values, we walk you through the exercise of adding negative numbers.
children.title: Adding negative numbers

children.tooltip: Let's a take stab at adding numbers with both positive and negative signs. Using a number line makes this exercise easier and we recommend it.
children.title: Adding numbers with different signs

children.tooltip: Logic tells us (as does this video) that subtracting a negative number is the same thing as adding the absolute value of that number. Watch and be amazed.
children.title: Subtracting a negative = adding a positive

children.tooltip: Let's challenge ourselves with a word problem that requires us to plot points, positive and negative, and find the difference.
children.title: Negative number word problem

children.tooltip: Your checking account is overdrawn. Not good. Use your knowledge of decimals and adding negative and positive numbers to bring your account back into the black.
children.title: Rational number word problem with decimals

children.tooltip: Adding and subtracting negative numbers
children.title: Adding/subtracting negative numbers
Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
children.tooltip:
It is starting to dawn on you that negative numbers are incredibly awesome.  So awesome that you are feeling embarrassed to think how excited you are about them!

Well, the journey is just beginning.  In this tutorial we will think about multiplying and dividing numbers throughout the number line!
Here we explain some rules of thumb regarding the multiplication of positive and negative numbers.
children.title: Multiplying positive and negative numbers

children.tooltip: Why are the products of negative numbers defined in the way they are? We'll use the distributive property to help you with your understanding.
children.title: Why a negative times a negative is a positive

children.tooltip: We use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an intuitive understanding of multiplying negative numbers.
children.title: Why a negative times a negative makes intuitive sense

children.tooltip: In this video we take you through the basics of dividing with negative numbers. You'll need to draw from your multiplication skills, too.
children.title: Dividing positive and negative numbers

children.tooltip: Help us find the product of numbers with different signs.
children.title: Multiplying numbers with different signs

children.tooltip: Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
children.title: Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
Absolute value
children.tooltip:
You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero."  If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value.  If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value.  

As you'll see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extend to more contexts and dimensions, so it's super important that you understand this core concept now.
One easy way to think of absolute value is the distance it is from zero. To do that, a number line comes in handy. Watch and learn.
children.title: Absolute value and number lines

children.tooltip: Not only will we identify several absolute values in this example, but we will order them from smallest to largest. Content provided by The NROC Project - Â©Monterey Institute for Technology and Education
children.title: Absolute value smallest to biggest

children.tooltip: Let's mix a little algebra into our discussion of absolute value. What if we are looking for the |x|? If we know what x equals, we can do it. Follow along.
children.title: Absolute value of integers

children.tooltip: When we compare numbers we use the concepts of greater than (>), less than (<), and equal to (=). The same is true of absolute values.
children.title: Comparing absolute values

children.tooltip: Here are a few word problems that ask us to apply our new absolute value knowledge. As with all word problems, read them a couple of times before jumping to an answer.
children.title: Absolute value word problems

children.tooltip: Watch as we apply our understanding of absolute value and adding/subtracting negative numbers to solve some word problems.
children.title: Constructing and interpreting absolute value
Factors and multiples
children.tooltip: Understanding and finding factors and multiples. After these videos, you'll be ready for fractions.

children.title: Divisibility tests
children.tooltip: Whether you are trying to impress your dog's friends (who are obsessed with figuring out number divisibility) or quickly factor a number, it can be very useful to tell whether a number is divisible by another.  This tutorial walks through some of the more standard divisibility methods and describes why they work.
Worked example of basic divisibility tests
children.title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10

children.tooltip: Recognizing Divisibility
children.title: Recognizing divisibility

children.tooltip: Why you can add the digits to see if something is divisible by 3
children.title: The why of the 3 divisibility rule

children.tooltip: Why you can test divisibility by 9 by just adding the digits
children.title: The why of the 9 divisibility rule
Divisibility and factors
children.tooltip: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!
To find the factors of a number means to find all the whole numbers that the number in question is divisible by. Can you help us find the factors in this example?
children.title: Finding factors of a number

children.tooltip: Watch and listen as we explain a simple way of remembering the difference between factors and multiples.
children.title: Finding factors and multiples

children.tooltip: Here's a video of Sal working on a exercise which helps you visualize the process of finding a number's factors.
children.title: Interactive module: finding factors
Prime numbers
children.tooltip: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.
What does it mean to be a prime number? Let's progress though some whole numbers and ask ourselves if they meet the criteria. What is the criteria you ask? Watch.
children.title: Prime numbers

children.tooltip: Can you recognize the prime numbers in this group of numbers? Which are prime, composite, or neither?
children.title: Recognizing prime and composite numbers
Prime factorization
children.tooltip: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!
Prime Factorization
children.title: Prime factorization

children.tooltip: None
children.title: Prime factorization exercise

children.tooltip: Ben Eater and Sal walk through the "Fundamental theorem of arithmetic" module: http://www.khanacademy.org/math/arithmetic/factors-multiples/e/the_fundamental_theorem_of_arithmetic
children.title: The fundamental theorem of arithmetic

children.tooltip: Common Divisibility Examples
children.title: Common divisibility examples
Least common multiple
children.tooltip: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.
We're practicing finding the least common multiple in these example exercises. We'll teach you the prime factorization approach which is a pretty nifty way to find the lcm (least common multiple).
children.title: Least common multiple exercise

children.tooltip: Here's a lcm (least common multiple) example exercise that's a little but harder, but totally doable. Again, we'll use the prime factorization approach.
children.title: Least common multiple exercise 2

children.tooltip: This least common multiple example gives us 3 numbers from which to find the lcm. This is a challenge, but fun. Do it with us!
children.title: Least common multiple exercise: 3 numbers
Greatest common factor
children.tooltip: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!
Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries, we'll show you how to do it.
children.title: Greatest common factor exercise

children.tooltip: Here's a nice explanation of least common factor (or least common divisor) along with a few practice example exercises. Let's roll.
children.title: Greatest common factor explained

children.tooltip: Here we have a couple of word problems--one searching for the least common multiple and the other for the greatest common factor. Just read them with us slowly and follow along. You'll get it.
children.title: LCM and GCF word problems
Decimals
children.tooltip: None

children.title: Conceptualizing decimals and place notation
children.tooltip: You've been using decimals all of your life.  When you pay $0.75 at a vending machine, 0.75 is a decimal.  When you see the ratings of gymnastics judges at the Olympics ("9.5, 9.4, 7.5 (booooo)"), those are decimals.  This tutorial will help you understand this powerful tool all the better.  Before you know it, you'll be representing numbers that are in-between whole numbers all the time!
Decimal Place Value
children.title: Decimal place value

children.tooltip: By writing out a decimal in words, you're forced to really show your understanding of it. Give it a try!
children.title: Decimals: writing it out in words

children.tooltip: Here's another example involving writing out a decimal in words. Great practice.
children.title: Decimals: writing it out in words 2

children.tooltip: Let's expand a decimal out and really try to understand what it represents.
children.title: Decimals: expanding out place value

children.tooltip: Take your time and remember your order of operations as you translate this into a decimal number.
children.title: Decimals: writing it out as a number

children.tooltip: We're having a blast with decimals! Check this one: we're comparing place values. This will blow your mind.
children.title: Decimals: comparing place values

children.tooltip: Let's decide the number of each place value to make the given decimal. We can do it together!
children.title: Decimals: choosing a number to represent place value
Regrouping decimals
children.tooltip: Let's explore how we can regroup and redistribute value among the various place values in a decimal number.
We're doing more regrouping but this time using decimals. Just remember those place values!
children.title: Regrouping with decimals

children.tooltip: Similar to a problem we did earlier but with whole numbers, this time we're having to regroup with decimals and find the right answer. Take your time.
children.title: Regrouping with decimals example 1

children.tooltip: Great decimal regrouping exercise. Do this one with us and see how well you've mastered the regrouping decimal topic!
children.title: Regrouping decimals example 2
Decimals on a number line
children.tooltip: Let's think about where decimals are on a number line.  It will help us understand what decimals represent in general!
Let's compare decimals on a number line, shall we?
children.title: Decimals on a number line

children.tooltip: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.
children.title: Decimals and fractions on a number line

children.tooltip: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.
children.title: Placing positive and negative decimals on a number line
Comparing decimals
children.tooltip: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!
When comparing decimals it's easy to get confused by the number of digits to the right of decimal. Is it a tenth, hundredth, or thousandth? This video will help you a lot!
children.title: Comparing decimals example 1

children.tooltip: We're using the less than () symbols to compare decimals now. Cool!
children.title: Comparing decimals example 2

children.tooltip: Confused trying to determine which decimal is larger? Let's compare two decimals in this example. Remember that you're looking for the difference is the largest place value to find the larger decimal.
children.title: Comparing decimals: difference in largest place value

children.tooltip: It's not uncommon to be asked to compare two decimals and judge which one is larger. How do you do that? This video will gave you the confidence to answer that question.
children.title: Comparing decimals: place value difference

children.tooltip: This is a fun example where we reorder decimals from smallest to largest. You're looking for the place value that is the most signifiant, and then working backwards.
children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from least to greatest

children.tooltip: Let's move the decimals around and reorder them from least to greatest. Hint: look at one place value and then compare it to the decimals before moving on to the next place value.
children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from smallest to biggest
Adding and subtracting decimals
children.tooltip: You get the general idea of decimal is and what the digits in different places represent (place value).  Now you're ready to do something with the decimals.  Adding and subtracting is a good place to start.  This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally).  Have fun!
Line those decimals up first. Careful!
children.title: Adding decimals: example 1

children.tooltip: Let's practice another adding decimal problem. We'll do it together.
children.title: Adding decimals: example 2

children.tooltip: We're adding 3 decimal numbers together in this example. Give it a try!
children.title: Adding decimals: example 3

children.tooltip: Subtracting decimals...up to the hundredths placement. Line up those decimals before you start.
children.title: Subtracting decimals: example 1

children.tooltip: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.
children.title: Subtracting decimals example 1

children.tooltip: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work. We sound like a broken record, but be sure and ALIGN DECIMALS.

children.tooltip: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.
children.title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problem

children.tooltip: Subtracting decimal numbers
children.title: Subtracting decimals (old)
Multiplying decimals
children.tooltip: The real world is seldom about whole numbers.  If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal.  If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).
Multiplying decimals can be confusing because there's always the question as to where the decimals goes in the answer. We're about to show you so you'll never have to question it again!
children.title: Introduction to multiplying decimals

children.tooltip: We're multiplying decimals again, but this time answering a common question: what's the cost of filling up the car tank?
children.title: Multiplying decimals word problem

children.tooltip: We want you to develop an intuition about how to work with decimals. Understanding how you can rewrite decimals by considering the place value will help you multiply!
children.title: Multiplying decimals: place value and reordering

children.tooltip: Multiplying decimals? Try multiplying without the decimals first, them add them back in. We'll show you.
children.title: Multiplying decimals example

children.tooltip: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.
children.title: Multiplying challenging decimals
Dividing decimals
children.tooltip: You can add, subtract and multiply decimals.  You know you'd feel a bit empty if you couldn't divide them as well. But something more powerful is going to happen.  If you are like us, you never quite liked those pesky remainders when dividing whole numbers.  Well, those pesky remainders better watch out because they are going to be divided too!!!! Ah ha ha ha ha!!!!!
Sometimes, in order divide numbers completely you have to add a decimal and bring down places. Let's do it together, shall we?
children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer

children.tooltip: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is smaller than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.
children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2

children.tooltip: You're doing great. Now we want to mix it up a little: divide a decimal by a whole number. Follow along.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a whole number

children.tooltip: When dividing a whole number by a decimal, you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.
children.title: Dividing a whole number by a decimal

children.tooltip: Let's do one more decimal division problem together but change it up. This is one with a decimal divisor and will require you to shift the decimal first.
children.title: Dividing by a multi-digit decimal

children.tooltip: The old saying is "practice makes perfect." Let's keep practicing dividing decimals and making our divisor a whole number.
children.title: Dividing decimals with hundredths example 3
Converting between fractions and decimals
children.tooltip: Both fractions and decimals are desperate to capture that little part of our heart that desires to express non-whole numbers.  But must we commit?  Can't we have business in the front and party in the back (younger people should look up the word "mullet" to see a hair-style worth considering for your next trip to the barber)?  Can't it look like a pump, but feel like a sneaker?  Well, if 18-wheelers can turn into self-righteous robots, then why can't decimals and fractions turn into each other?
Sometimes when you convert a fraction to a decimal you have to do some long division and rounding.
children.title: Fraction to decimal with rounding

children.tooltip: This is a great example of converting a fraction to a decimal. Use a scratch pad so you can follow along.

children.tooltip: How to express a fraction as a decimal
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals

children.tooltip: Converting fractions to decimals sometimes requires us to brush up on our long division skills. We'll walk you through it.

children.tooltip: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.
children.title: Decimal to simplified fraction

children.tooltip: We're practicing how to convert a lonely decimal into a happy fraction.

children.tooltip: Being a decimal is hard. Everyone picks on you. Not like those lucky fractions. Let's convert the decimal together.

Intro to percentages
children.tooltip: None
Let's start by thinking about what percent really means. Once you understand this, other pieces will begin to fall into place.
children.title: The meaning of percent

children.tooltip: How does our meaning of percent (per "hundred") translate when we need to understand a percent OVER a hundred?
children.title: The meaning of percent over 100

children.tooltip: You'll find that be able to move easily between percentages, decimals, and fractions is HUGELY helpful. So let's practice!
children.title: Converting percent to decimal and fraction

children.tooltip: Need to convert a decimal to a percent? Ok, we'll just use our fraction friends to get us there. Watch and be amazed.
children.title: Converting decimals to percents

children.tooltip: Understanding how to convert a decimal to a percent comes in really handy sometimes. Let's practice using this problem.

children.tooltip: Remember that "per cent" means "per hundred." Knowing that, converting a percent to a decimal is done by dividing by a 100. We'll demonstrate.
children.title: Converting percents to decimals

children.tooltip: Practice another conversion problem, this time from percent to decimal. Arriving at the answer is as simple as dividing by 100!
children.title: Converting percents to decimals example 2

children.tooltip: Once again, fractions are our friends as we use them to find a percentage. You'll also see a couple of different ways to arrive at the answer.

children.tooltip: We hope you're beginning to see that there's more than one way to skin a cat. In other words, there are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages, decimals, and fractions. Watch as find the percentage of a whole number.

Percent word problems
children.tooltip: Whether you're calculating a tip at your favorite restaurant or figuring out how many decades you'll be paying your student debt because of the interest, percents will show up again and again and again in your life.  This tutorial will expose you to some of these problems before they show up in your actual life so you can handle them with ease (kind of like a vaccine for the brain).  Enjoy.
In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.
children.title: Growing by a percentage

children.tooltip: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.
children.title: Solving percent problems

children.tooltip: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.
children.title: Percent word problem example 4

children.tooltip: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage.We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!
children.title: Percent word problem example 5
Estimating and rounding with decimals
children.tooltip:
Laziness is usually considered a bad thing.  But sometimes, it is useful to be lazy in a smart way.  Why do a big, hairy calculation if you just need a rough estimate? Why keep track of 2.345609 when you only need 2.35? 

This tutorial will get you comfortable with sometimes being a little rough with numbers.  By being able to round and estimate them, it'll only add one more tool to your toolkit.
Rounding. Oh my....there will be so many times when rounding numbers (including decimals) will be a required skill. Let's get this down, shall we?
children.title: Rounding decimals: to the nearest tenth
Significant figures
children.tooltip:
There is a strong temptation in life to appear precise, even when you are aren't accurate.   If you  precisely measure one dimension of a carpet to be 3.256 meters and eyeball the other dimensional to be "roughly 2 meters", can you really claim that the area is  6.512 square meters (3.256 x 2)?  Isn't that a little misleading?  

This tutorial gets us thinking about this conundrum and gives us the best practices that scientists and engineers use to not mislead each other.
Introduction to significant figures
children.title: Significant figures

children.tooltip: Understanding the "rules of thumb" for significant figures
children.title: More on significant figures

children.tooltip: Addition and Subtraction with Significant Figures
children.title: Addition and subtraction with significant figures

children.tooltip: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures
children.title: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures
Moving the decimal to multiply and divide by 10
children.tooltip: In our decimal number system, as we move places to the left, the place values increase by a factor of 10 (likewise, they decrease by a factor of 10 as we move rightward).  This idea gets direct application when we multiply or divide a decimal number by 10 because it has the effect of shifting every place value one to the right or left (sometime seen as moving the decimal point).
You will notice in this word problem that moving the decimal to the right the same number of times as the number of zeros you multiplying by gets you the answer you desire. Check this out!
children.title: Multiplying a decimal by a power of 10

children.tooltip: When we were multiplying, we moved the decimal to the right for each power of ten. Guess what? When dividing, we move the decimal to the left for each power of ten.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10

children.tooltip: Holy cow! A shortcut? Yep. For each ten you multiply or divide by, just shift that decimal to the right or left. Watch this and be amazed.
children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10: shortcut
Adding and subtracting decimals percentages and fractions
children.tooltip: If you think you know how to convert between decimals, fractions and percentages and are familiar with negative numbers, this tutorial is a good place to test all of those skills at the same time.

In this example, we solve an addition problem with numbers in different formats: a percentage, decimal, and mixed number. First, we'll get them all in the same format...which makes it a while easier to solve!
children.title: Adding, subtracting numbers in different formats

children.tooltip: What happens when we are asked to add or subtract fractions, decimals, and percentages? You'll see in this example that we first get them in the same format, and then add fractions.
children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions, decimals, percentages

children.tooltip: Our focus here is on learning to multiply fractions. First we have to get the common denominator, then add positive and negative numbers.
children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions
Fractions
children.tooltip: None

children.title: Understanding fractions
children.tooltip:
If you don't understand fractions, you won't be even 1/3 educated.  Glasses will seem half empty rather than half full.  You'll be lucky to not be duped into some type of shady real-estate scheme or putting far too many eggs in your cake batter.

Good thing this tutorial is here.  You'll see that fractions allow us to view the world in entirely new ways.  You'll see that everything doesn't have to be a whole.  You'll be able to slice and dice and then put it all back together (and if you order now, we'll throw in a spatula warmer for no extra charge).
None

Visualizing equivalent fractions
children.tooltip: Do you want 2/3 or 4/6 of this pizza?  Doesn't matter because they are both the same fraction.  This tutorial will help us explore this idea by really visualizing what equivalent fractions represent.
To understand equivalent fractions it helps to "see" the fractions using something like a grid with shaded and unshaded sections representing the fraction. This will help a ton!
children.title: Visualizing equivalent fractions

children.tooltip: Your teachers will tell you that being able to apply (or put to use) concepts helps you to learn them better. Here's a word problem in which you have to apply your knowledge of equivalent fractions.
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example

children.tooltip: How do you find an equivalent fraction? If you know the denominator of both fractions, and the numerator of one of them...you can figure out the rest We'll show you in this word problem.
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 2

children.tooltip: We're comparing fractions using the info given in this word problem. Can you find the equivalent one?
children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 3
Equivalent fractions and simplified form
children.tooltip:
There are literally infinite ways to represent any fraction (or number for that matter).  Don't believe us?  Let's take 1/3.  2/6, 3/9, 4/12 ... 10001/30003 are all equivalent fractions (and we could keep going)!  

If you know the basics of what a fraction is, this is a great tutorial for recognizing when fractions are equivalent and then simplifying them as much as possible!
Fractions in lowest terms

children.tooltip: Introduces the concept of equivalent fractions
children.title: Equivalent fractions

children.tooltip: How may times have you been told, "Save your money!" We thought so. What if you wanted to save a fractional amount of your allowance? How would you go about figuring out how much to save?

children.tooltip: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

Decomposing fractions
children.tooltip: In this tutorial, we'll see that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.  You might see the world in a completely different way after this.
It helps to visually understand what decomposing a fraction looks like. We're pretty sure you're going to like this.

children.tooltip: Decomposing mixed numbers is a pretty straightforward process. It's as simple as adding fractions with like denominators. Watch us do it!
children.title: Decomposing a mixed number

Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
children.tooltip: We've already had some good practice adding fractions with like denominators.  We'll now add fractions with unlike denominators. This is a very big deal.  After this tutorial, you'll be able to add, pretty much, any two (or three or four or... ) fractions!
A great way to learn how to add fractions with unlike demoninators is to do so with denominators in units of 10 and 100. Like this...
children.title: Adding fractions with unlike denominators: units of 10

children.tooltip: How to add and subtract fractions.
children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions

children.tooltip: To solve this problem, we need to find the least common multiple to get at the common denominator. Can you help? We bet you can!

children.tooltip: To add these fractions we need to find a common denominator. The answer can be expressed as a mixed number. Let's try together.

children.tooltip: If you conquered adding fractions with different denominators, then subtracting fractions will be a snap. Don't worry...we'll take it slow and explain every step.
